required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intravenous Insulin vs Subcutaneous Insulin Infusion in Intrapartum Management of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus
clinical_study.official_title: Intravenous Insulin Versus Subcutaneous Insulin Infusion in Intrapartum Management of Pregnant Women With Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus: A Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to perform a randomized trial to investigate if intrapartum insulin delivery mechanisms reduces adverse outcomes associated with type 1 diabetes in pregnancy. The investigators aim to compare subcutaneous insulin pump versus intravenous insulin infusion with regard to the primary outcome of neonatal blood sugar.

detailed_description.textblock:
Intrapartum glucose management is critical to reducing neonatal hypoglycemia shortly after birth. Some providers are comfortable continuing patients on their subcutaneous insulin pump during labor while others transition these patients to intravenous insulin infusions. Previous literature has retrospectively shown this to be both a feasible and safe option.
The investigators aim to compare subcutaneous insulin pump versus intravenous insulin infusion with regard to obstetric and neonatal outcomes.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a prospective, single-center, randomized study evaluating intrapartum insulin delivery management strategies among pregnant women with type 1 diabetes mellitus.
study_design_info.masking_description: Those assessing the outcomes from the medical chart will be blinded to the randomization process and the assigned study arm. Patients, the primary investigator, and their care providers will be aware of their treatment status.

primary_outcome.description: First neonatal blood sugar obtained within 2 hours of birth

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of maternal intrapartum glucose measurements
secondary_outcome.description: Number of maternal intrapartum glucose measurements

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal glucose values
secondary_outcome.description: Each maternal glucose values obtained during labor

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of maternal hypoglycemic events
secondary_outcome.description: Number of maternal blood sugars < 60 mg/dL

secondary_outcome.measure: Development of Diabetic Ketoacidosis during labor
secondary_outcome.description: Development of Diabetic Ketoacidosis during labor

secondary_outcome.measure: Mode of Delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Mode of Delivery (vaginal versus cesarean)

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Birthweight
secondary_outcome.description: Neonatal Birthweight

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with shoulder dystocia
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants with shoulder dystocia

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with brachial plexus injury
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants with brachial plexus injury

secondary_outcome.measure: Apgar Score
secondary_outcome.description: Neonatal Apgar Score

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal mean glucose level
secondary_outcome.description: Neonatal mean glucose level in first 24 hours of life

secondary_outcome.measure: Received neonatal intervention for hypoglycemia
secondary_outcome.description: Received intervention for hypoglycemia (any oral, IV, or both)

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At delivery and within first 2 day of life
secondary_outcome.description: Admission to level 2 or greater neonatal ICU and length of stay

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Admission for hypoglycemia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At delivery and within first 2 day of life
secondary_outcome.description: Admission to level 2 or greater neonatal ICU for hypoglycemia and length of stay

secondary_outcome.measure: Gestational age at delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Gestational age at delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with neonatal respiratory distress
secondary_outcome.description: Requiring 2 or more hours of respiratory support or oxygen with associated diagnosis

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with neonatal hyperbilirubinemia
secondary_outcome.description: Requiring phototherapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from birth to first neonatal glucose measurement
secondary_outcome.description: Time from birth to first neonatal glucose measurement

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal Care Satisfaction Survey
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postpartum, assessed within 4 days of delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Survey assessing satisfaction with healthcare provided

secondary_outcome.measure: Placental Pathology
secondary_outcome.description: Assessing for malperfusion pathology

secondary_outcome.measure: Umbilical Cord Blood Level of C-peptide

secondary_outcome.measure: Umbilical Cord Blood Level of Leptin
secondary_outcome.description: Umbilical Cord Blood Level of Leptin

secondary_outcome.measure: Umbilical Cord Blood Level of Insulin
secondary_outcome.description: Umbilical Cord Blood Level of Insulin

arm_group.description: Patients will be randomized to discontinuation of the CSII pump intrapartum and initiation of IV insulin infusion per hospital protocol.
Patients will be randomized to continuation of their CSII pump intrapartum and will be managed in accordance with the CSII hospital protocol.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women with pre-gestational diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus and managed on an insulin pump in pregnancy
- Pregnancy and delivery care obtained at University of Massachusetts (UMass) Memorial Medical Center
- Patients able to provide written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are under the age of 18
- Patients with altered state of consciousness
- Critically ill patient requiring intensive care unit admission
- Patient at risk for suicide
- Patient refuses or is otherwise unable to participate in own care
- Patient without pump supplies
- Patients presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis on admission

facility.name: University of Massachusetts Memorial Medical Center

reference.citation: Feldberg D, Dicker D, Samuel N, Peleg D, Karp M, Goldman JA. Intrapartum management of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) gestants. A comparative study of constant intravenous insulin infusion and continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion pump (CSIIP). Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 1988;67(4):333-8.

Professional Practice Committee for the Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes-2016. Diabetes Care. 2016 Jan;39 Suppl 1:S107-8. doi: 10.2337/dc16-S018.

Drever E, Tomlinson G, Bai AD, Feig DS. Insulin pump use compared with intravenous insulin during labour and delivery: the INSPIRED observational cohort study. Diabet Med. 2016 Sep;33(9):1253-9. doi: 10.1111/dme.13106. Epub 2016 Mar 20.

Fresa R, Visalli N, Di Blasi V, Cavallaro V, Ansaldi E, Trifoglio O, Abbruzzese S, Bongiovanni M, Agrusta M, Napoli A. Experiences of continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion in pregnant women with type 1 diabetes during delivery from four Italian centers: a retrospective observational study. Diabetes Technol Ther. 2013 Apr;15(4):328-34. doi: 10.1089/dia.2012.0260. Epub 2013 Mar 28.
